About
About
A global perspective shaped by living and working in six countries—from main urban centers to remote traditional villages. 

My journey is anchored in a deep relationship with nature, focusing on regeneration, connection, and healing.

At the heart of my work for the past 20 years are two unique sanctuaries—Picinguaba and Catuçaba—dedicated to the regeneration of humans and nature, combining eco-architecture, integral health, and sustainable living. 

I am committed to creating environments that foster deep reconnection between humans and the Earth. Through WeAreNature, my work is grounded in Earth-based principles, prioritizing traditional living and long-term impact.

---

Key Experiences & Initiatives

- Nature-Based Hospitality: Picinguaba and Catuçaba exemplify nature-to-table food, permaculture, land regeneration, and advanced sustainable practices, inspiring consciousness evolution and personal transformation. 
- Remote Sacred Sites Specialist: I’ve traveled across the five continents for the past 3 decades, learning from indigenous guardians and ancient Earth-based traditions that shape meaningful decisions and connections with the land and the planet.
- Global Network: I established the WAN group, a confidential network of benevolent individuals across major global capitals, aligned by shared elevated values and committed to humanity evolution. 
- Long-Term Vision : Over 20 years of practical experience I have framed a scalable model for deep reconnection, sustainability, and healing, which I am dedicated to further developing and expanding.

---

Core Values & Purpose

- Human Evolution from Within: humanity’s evolution begins with the individual. Lasting collective change requires dedicated places where people can slow down, reconnect with themselves, and engage deeply with the natural world.
- Unity Through Nature : Earth is just an h away from Heart: our shared Earth is what connects us. By embracing our commonalities through nature, we can foster reconciliation and harmony. There is a space to be beyond ecology. We are like leaves of the same tree, breathing the same air and powered by the same life-force.

---

Through WeAreNature, my mission is to blend ancient wisdom with practical approaches to create sustainable models for the future. I aim to inspire meaningful change by bringing together people and places, fostering deep reconnection with the Earth and a conscious, joyful way of living.

---

Emmanuel Rengade 🌎
Emmanuel Rengade 🌎
 • 1st
1st
Founder at WeAreNature.com | Regenerative Hideaways in Brazil | Steward of the Earth | Ancestral Wisdom | Universal Citizen
Founder at WeAreNature.com | Regenerative Hideaways in Brazil | Steward of the Earth | Ancestral Wisdom | Universal Citizen
1w • 
 
1 week ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
BEYOND ECOLOGY

The ecological movement, once at the center of our collective consciousness, seems to be losing momentum. And perhaps that’s not such a bad thing. Perhaps there's another, better way.

It was always hard to believe anyway that it could truly “win.” That the well-intentioned few could sway the unconscious majority. Eventually, what seemed like good ideas—planting trees, electric cars, renewable energy—wasn’t really working at the end: most trees don’t survive if you don’t nurture them, electric cars create another issues with batteries, etc. Ecological change seemed more intentional and peripheral than real. 

At some point, we must admit that the narrative became frustrating—heavy with guilt, tinged with hopelessness, and dominated by the language of fear. A vision of the future defined not by possibility, but by “points of no return.” 

But if we believe our thoughts shape our reality—why are we continuing to create this one? 

It may be time for a different approach. Not a war between “good ecologists” and “bad polluters”. Not guilt or blame, but collective responsibility. We can elevate ourselves and see from a wiser perspective. 

A new path is emerging—one that reconciles ecological awareness with deeper truths about healing, oneness, and our shared humanity.

 We can make the choice to responsibly self-actualize our ecological opinions to something more joyful and real, and that can bring true change.
 
Ancient and indigenous wisdom traditions have pointed to this all along: The Earth’s collapse mirrors the collapse of the human spirit. 

Our thoughts are creative forces. They can lead to destruction—or harmony. If we truly want to heal the Earth, we must first heal what we’ve lost within ourselves.

That means reconnecting with values that are not only humanistic, but spiritual. It suggests that ecology, as central and essential as it may have seemed to us, might in fact be just a path toward a deeper rediscovery: our connection with the Earth. Or shall we say to be more precise: our love for the Earth, and the love of the Earth for us.

And this is good news, because love speaks higher than any ism.
Beyond ideology. Beyond partisanship. Rooted in truth, simplicity, and presence. 

When we stop projecting blame and instead turn inward, we connect with something essential and inexpressable with words and mind. Unity. Coherence. 

Ecology is but a path to Love: let’s really cross that bridge.

And from there, right action emerges—not as obligation, but as a natural flow.

It’s time to go deeper into nature. Not just physically—but consciously.
 With openness. With humility. With the courage to change the way we see the world.
…more

Founder and Director, Instituto Sinal do Vale. Co-chair advisory council UN Decade for Ecosystems Restoration
Founder and Director, Instituto Sinal do Vale. Co-chair advisory council UN Decade for Ecosystems Restoration
3mo • 
 
3 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
Lugares que Curam, Inspiram e Regeneram! 

Na semana passada, visitei dois lugares extraordinários: Catuçaba e Picinguaba – We Are Nature. Ambos me tocaram profundamente pela sua beleza, coerência e propósito. Assim como o SINAL do Vale, são muito mais do que hospedagens ou empreendimentos. São territórios vivos — lugares que acolhem, regeneram e mostram um outro caminho possível para o nosso futuro coletivo.

Vivemos tempos em que a reconexão com a natureza não é mais um luxo, mas uma necessidade vital. Como tão bem expõe o artigo da iniciativa We Are Nature — “7 reasons why we need places in nature” — esses espaços:
restauram nossa saúde física e emocional,
resgatam a sabedoria do tempo natural,
inspiram novas formas de viver, produzir e liderar.
Lugares como Catuçaba, Picinguaba e SINAL do Vale são sementes de um futuro regenerativo. Eles nos lembram que é possível viver em harmonia com a Terra, gerar impacto positivo e ao mesmo tempo criar experiências transformadoras para pessoas, comunidades e organizações. Precisamos fortalecer essa rede de territórios regenerativos — conectando práticas, saberes, soluções e narrativas. Eles são pontos de transição entre o modelo que está colapsando e o mundo que queremos construir.

Mais do que nunca, o planeta precisa de lugares assim. E nós também. 🌿

Places that Heal, Inspire and Regenerate! 
Last week, I had the joy of visiting two extraordinary places: Catuçaba and Picinguaba – We Are Nature. Both touched me deeply — not only for their natural beauty, but for the coherence and purpose that permeate every detail. Like SINAL do Vale, these are not just hospitality ventures. They are living sanctuaries — places that welcome, regenerate, and show us another possible path for our shared future.
In our times, reconnection with nature is no longer a luxury — it is a vital need. As beautifully expressed in We Are Nature's article “7 reasons why we need places in nature”, these spaces:
restore our physical and emotional well-being,
reconnect us with the wisdom of natural time,
inspire new ways of living, producing, and leading.
Places like Catuçaba, Picinguaba, and SINAL do Vale are seeds of a regenerative future. They remind us that it is possible to live in harmony with the Earth, generate positive impact, and create meaningful, transformative experiences for people, communities, and organizations.
🌍 Now is the time to strengthen this network of regenerative territories — to connect practices, knowledge, solutions, and stories. These places are not isolated experiments: they are gateways between a collapsing system and the world we know is possible.
More than ever, the planet needs places like these. And so do we.
…more

Sao Paulo
Sao Paulo
Fazenda Catuçaba is a laboratory where a number of achievements were accomplished over the past few years, including the first Platinum LEED certified eco-house in South America, the first Oca (Indian House) built by indigenous people outside the Amazon, the fist Art Gallery away from the cities in Brazil, all landmark structures for new times that are being used for workshops, exhibitions, events, and direct experience of a new way of living. 

Our work involves getting back to the origins. The origin of hospitality, experiencing true kindness. The origin of food, living healthily. The origin of architecture, being in tune with our environment. The origin of Art, reaching to the invisible. The origin of education, freeing the soul. The origin of spirituality, returning to Nature.

Pousada Picinguaba
Pousada Picinguaba
Mar 2001 - Present · 24 yrs 8 mos
Mar 2001 to Present · 24 yrs 8 mos
Pousada Picinguaba is a small, ecological, understated hotel based on beautiful nature and beautiful people, located in the fishing village of Picinguaba. Pousada Picinguaba was quoted by the Financial Times in 2002 as “the first boutique hotel of Brazil”.

Entirely run by local people, the Pousada is set in one of the most beautiful stretch of the Brazilian Coastline, between Rio and Sao Paulo, in the middle of a Natural Park.
